item.title: India is enhancing its intellectual property infrastructure
item.description: The Indian government has decided to continue its efforts to improve its intellectual property (IP) offices. This initiative, part of the 12th Plan (2012-2017), will cost Rs309.6 crore, with Rs258 crore allocated for the 12th Plan and Rs51.6 crore for the 13th Plan. This decision recognizes the increasing importance of IP in a globalized economy, India’s recent membership in the Madrid Protocol (April 2013), and the Controller General of Patents, Designs, and Trademarks (CGPDTM) office’s new role as an International Searching and Preliminary Examining Authority (ISA/IPEA) under the Patent Cooperation Treaty (starting October 2013).

item.title: Singapore is dedicated to developing talent in the infocomm sector
item.description: Singapore’s Minister for Communications and Information, Dr. Yaacob Ibrahim, addressed the rising demand for infocomm professionals in the country. This surge is attributed to the growth of the ICT sector and Singapore’s Smart Nation initiatives. Dr. Yaacob emphasized the need to fill 30,000 infocomm positions by 2020. He acknowledged the challenge of meeting this demand solely with local talent, stating that while relying on non-Singaporeans might be necessary, the focus should be on equipping Singaporeans with highly competitive skills.

item.title: Tourists are disappointed with shopping in Singapore, while locals are loyal to their telecommunications companies
item.description: A study by the Institute of Service Excellence (ISES) at Singapore Management University reveals a drop in customer satisfaction within Singapore’s retail and info-communications sectors. item.title: This year in the Philippines, the focus is on mobile technology
item.description: In the Philippines, technology is synonymous with mobile technology. According to Jubert Alberto, Research Manager at IDC Philippines, “The younger generation is entering the workforce, and they have a strong desire to be connected, informed, and entertained. They also tend to have fewer dependents. These factors indicate a growing demand for all things mobile, including devices, services, and applications.” IDC predicts that the Philippines will experience a 22% rise in smartphone spending and a 40% increase in tablet expenditure in 2014, fueled by a positive economic outlook.
